sections.rawHtml:
Can fly for compensation or hire and can carry people or property for compensation or hire .

Need an Instrument Rating to fly people for compensation or hire on flight over 50 NM or at night .


Can Fly for hire for a commercial operator if you do not have operational control or you can fly under 119.1E Exceptions for hire

or you can fly under 91 for hire as long as the flying is incidental to the business and not the business itself.


Can't "Hold Out" - Advertise or build a reputation for flying the public.

definitions.rawText: The date is locked in when you get the medical so if you get it one day before turning 40 you get the full time.

Statement of Demonstrated Ability (SODA) - Can be given if you have a condition that doesn’t change over time but would normally disqualify you like an amputation or hearing impairment. Doesn't Expire.

Special Issuance Medical - Can be given if you have a condition that could get worse over time or flair back up like diabetes or previous substance abuse. Typically requires periodic reevaluations.

sections.rawHtml:
Make sure the equipment is not in reg on its TCDS.

If your aircraft has a Minimum Equipment list start there - Must be onboard aircraft.

Created from a MMEL - Master minimum Equipment List | General for type of aircraft

Next refer to the KOEL - Kinds of Operation Equipment List. Has different categories like day and night operations.

Then look at the Regulations like 91.205

Make sure there aren't any Airworthiness Directives requiring it.

Finally make sure you are comfortable flying without it.

The Inop Equipment must be at least either inspected, replaced, repaired, or removed at the next inspection.

sections.rawHtml:
91.417 39

Legally enforceable, issued by the FAA to correct an unsafe condition in an aircraft product.

Type of ADs -

  • One Time - One time modification
  • Recurring - Repeated checks or replacements
  • Emergency - Requires Immediate action
  • Time Limited - Can wait a certain # of Tach Hours or until next inspection
  • Conditional - Required if a specific thing happens like a prop strike
sections.rawText:
91.417 39
Legally enforceable, issued by the FAA to correct an unsafe condition in an aircraft product.
Type of ADs -
One Time - One time modification
Recurring - Repeated checks or replacements
Emergency - Requires Immediate action
Time Limited - Can wait a certain # of Tach Hours or until next inspection
Conditional - Required if a specific thing happens like a prop strike
sections.title: Airworthiness Directives

sections.rawHtml:
No difference in the inspection itself

Annuals need an A&P with Inspection Authorization (IA)

100 Hours only need an A&P

Annuals are certified as the Aircraft as a whole was inspected while

100 Hours should have a separate certification for each Airframe, Engine, and Prop

100 Hour be overflown by 10 hours to get to inspection location but counts for the next 100 hours

An annual can count as your 100 Hour but not the other way around

sections.rawHtml:
Part 43

Preventative Maintenance can be performed by an owner / operator that holds at least a private pilot license.

Defined as simple or minor preservation operations or the replacement of small standard parts not involving complex assembly.

Anything not in part 43 appendix A paragraph C is not preventative maintenance,

However things like adding oil or adding air to tires is considered basic upkeep and not listed as preventative maintenance.

Must log work - Description | Date | Name, Signature, Cert Number, and kind of Cert for the person who did the work.

definitions.rawText:
A line connecting the leading and trailing edge of the wing that goes through the exact middle of the wing showing its curvature. 
The more curvature (camber) the faster air goes over top which generates more lift but also drag. At lower airspeeds the drag is less noticeable and you get the extra lift and lower stall speeds.
However at higher speeds drag is increased a lot and would outweigh the benefits. Thats why we use flaps at lower speeds - they increase the camber of the wing.

Connects the leading and trailing edges of the wings in a straight line. 
Used to measure AoA - The angle between the chord line and relative wind.

sections.title: Camber / Chord Lines

definitions.rawText:
The aircraft's tendency to yaw in the opposite direction of the turn. 
Caused by the wing raised in the roll creating more lift and drag than the lower wing.
Corrected by using Rudder to coordinate the turn.

sections.title: Adverse Yaw

definitions.rawText: These are two common types of ailerons used to help negate adverse yaw

When the aileron is raised to lower the wing part of it now protrudes the bottom of the wing.
This creates additional form drag to counter act the extra drag the higher wing is getting.

One aileron is raised a greater distance than the other one is lowered 
This creates more drag on the lower wing counter acting the drag from the higher wing.

sections.title: Ailerons

sections.rawHtml:
Servo Trim Tabs - 172s has these which mean the trim tab moves the opposite direction of the elevator.

If you trim up it causes the elevator to be pushed down so you don't have to hold it down your self.


Ground Adjustable Tab - There is also a small tab on the rudder which is just a piece of metal you can bend by hand

to make sure the plane flies coordinated in level flight.

sections.rawHtml:
We have Electrically operated single slot flaps with 10, 20 and 30 degrees.

Single Slot Flaps - This means there is a gap that opens up between the wing and flap

which allows air from the below the wing to come up and reenergize the boundary layer between the air and wing,

this delays airflow separation and maintains that smooth laminar flow.


Flaps purpose is to produce more lift at a given AoA, produce more drag, and reduce landing roll.

Extra lift is produced by the new camber line, and the drag is beneficial in descending steeper without increasing airspeed.

The first 10 degrees of flaps primarily increases lift, and any more flaps produces much more drag.

sections.rawHtml:
Four Left Turning Tendencies

1: Torque Effect - Newtons Third Law = Every action has an equal and opposite reaction.

The action of the propeller spinning clockwise makes the aircraft roll in the opposite direction to the left. Worse at high power settings but engine is offset to counteract this.

2: *Gyroscopic Precession - When you pitch up force is applied to the bottom of the spinning propeller,

this then actually gets applied 90 degrees into the turn later which actually pushes the nose to the right,

It is only a left turning tendency in descents and actually counteracts some of the others, in tail draggers you pitch down to land so it add to them.
sections.rawText:
Four Left Turning Tendencies
1: Torque Effect - Newtons Third Law = Every action has an equal and opposite reaction.
The action of the propeller spinning clockwise makes the aircraft roll in the opposite direction to the left. Worse at high power settings but engine is offset to counteract this.
2: P Factor - In High angles of attack the downward moving blade is facing into the wind more so it has a higher angle of attack also.
This means it's generating more thrust on the right downward moving side generating more thrust and making a yaw to the left.
3: Spiraling Slipstream - At High power settings and low airspeeds the wind from the propeller spirals around the plane.
This eventually hits the vertical stabilizer on the left side pushing it creating a yaw to the left.
4: *Gyroscopic Precession - When you pitch up force is applied to the bottom of the spinning propeller,
this then actually gets applied 90 degrees into the turn later which actually pushes the nose to the right,
It is only a left turning tendency in descents and actually counteracts some of the others, in tail draggers you pitch down to land so it add to them.
sections.title: Left Turning Tendencies

sections.rawHtml:
The airflow directly opposite the aircrafts flight path.

Your angle of attack changes when you say increase your pitch but at a slower airspeed so your flight path

is still traveling the same direction but at a higher pitched up angle or angle of attack.


Angle of Attack - Is the Angle between the chord line and relative wind.

Meteorological Aerodrome Report

Reports showing current weather conditions around an airport.

Reports are released hourly 55 minutes after the hour.

Routine Conditions can be expected within a 5 SM radius of the airport.

SPECIs are unscheduled METARs released when there is a sudden or drastic change.

*VV or vertical visibility counts as a ceiling - caused by things like fog.
sections.rawText:
Meteorological Aerodrome Report
Reports showing current weather conditions around an airport.
Reports are released hourly 55 minutes after the hour. 
Routine Conditions can be expected within a 5 SM radius of the airport.
SPECIs are unscheduled METARs released when there is a sudden or drastic change. 
*VV or vertical visibility counts as a ceiling - caused by things like fog.
sections.title: METARs

sections.rawHtml:
Terminal Aerodrome Forecast

Reports of Forecasted Weather around an airport.

Has a radius of 5 SM from the center of the runway complex.

Issued 4 times a day every 6 hours and valid for 24 hours.

Really big airports might have ones valid for 30 hours.

FG is reported for visibility less than 5/8 SM - BR is reported when it is more then 5/8 SM.
sections.rawText:
Terminal Aerodrome Forecast
Reports of Forecasted Weather around an airport.
Has a radius of 5 SM from the center of the runway complex. 
Issued 4 times a day every 6 hours and valid for 24 hours.
Really big airports might have ones valid for 30 hours. 
FG is reported for visibility less than 5/8 SM - BR is reported when it is more then 5/8 SM.

sections.rawHtml:
Pilot Reports depicting real-time weather conditions, Altitudes in MSL.

Include the location, time, and type of plane.

Labelled either UA for routine or UUA for Urgent.

Urgent reports are for things like tornados | severe turbulence | low level wind shear etc.

Can be submitted to ATC by radio or to a FSS .

Can be accessed from foreflight on the ground or ATC/FSS in the air.

sections.title: PIREPs

definitions.rawText: Chart is issued every 3 hours

A line of fast moving cold air the pushes warmer air upward aggressively leading to thunderstorms and bad weather. Signs of one are a high dew point and falling barometric pressure.
Weather it can cause included cumulonimbus clouds, unstable air, heavy showers, temperature and dew point and pressure drop, after passage weather clears quickly.
Warm air gradually slides over top of a colder air mass leading to warmer temperatures, low ceilings and visibility, steady rain, weather can linger longer than in a cold front.
Occurs when two air masses of similar strength meet and leads to a mixture of weather from both fronts.

A fast moving cold front catches up to a slower moving warm front, as it approaches expect warm front weather followed immediately by cold front weather.
Can be either a cold or warm front occlusion based on if the air in front of the warm front is warmer or colder than the cold front. Warm Front Occlusions can be severe and convective.
Connect lines of equal pressure - Lines closer together indicate a steep pressure gradient which makes air more inclined to move
An elongated area of low pressure
Air flows Counter Clockwise, Inward, and Upward, which generally leads to worse weather and unstable air.
Air flows Clockwise, Outward, and Downward which generally leads to more stable conditions.

sections.rawHtml:
All weather is the result of a heat exchange

Pressure differences create wind flowing from high to low

Temperature decreases -2 C per 1000 ft with a normal lapse rate and stops at the tropopause

Lower levels of atmosphere where weather occurs are Troposphere | Tropopause | Stratosphere

Air is composed of 78 % Nitrogen and 21 % Oxygen and 1 % other


Air Masses

Tropical - Forrest

sections.rawHtml:
Airmen's Meteorological Information

AIRMETs are forecast weather advisories depicting where moderate hazards may occur.

Issued every 6 hours and valid for 6 hours

Three Types:

Tango - Moderate Turbulence | Low Level Wind Shear | Sustained Surface Winds of 30 Knots or more.

Sierra - Ceilings Less than 1000 ft and/or visibility less than 3 SM affecting over 50 % of the area.

Zulu - Moderate Icing | Provides Freezing Level Heights

sections.rawHtml:
Significant Meteorological Information

SIGMETs are forecast weather advisories depicting significant hazards

These are Unscheduled generally valid up to 4 hours for areas of at least 3000 square miles

Include: Severe Icing | Severe Turbulence | Mountain Waves | Dust / Sandstorms with < 3 SM Visibility | Volcanic Ash

sections.rawHtml:
The atmosphere is made up of 78 % Nitrogen and 21 % Oxygen

The three lowest layers and ones notable for aviation are

Troposphere - Where almost all weather takes place, Up to around 36,000 ft

Standard lapse rate of -2 C per 1000 ft, and pressure decreases by 1 inch Hg.

Tropopause - Boundary Layer between tropo and strato spheres.

Lapse rate goes down to zero

Stratosphere - Commercial aircraft often cruise in the lower stratosphere to avoid weather.

Lapse rate reverses slightly

sections.rawHtml:
Observations generated every 4 - 11 minutes valid from the end of the last scan.

Generated in the US by Doppler Radars which make up the NEXRAD system used by NWS and FAA.

Doppler Radar - Sends out signals that reflect or echo off of precipitation, it measures the reflective power of this and the higher the more intense precipitation.

A radar echo is just its appearance / color on a radar display.

Shows precipitation not cloud coverage

Beams can miss certain areas or be obstructed

sections.rawHtml:
Atmospheric Stability is the ability to resist vertical motion.

In a stable atmosphere air pushed up will quickly stop rising, and in an unstable one it will keep rising.

The Stability is determined by the Temperature and Moisture of the atmosphere.

Cool and dry air is stable - Warm and Wet air is unstable

Warm air rises and water vapor is lighter than air so less dense and rises more.

sections.rawHtml:
Wind is caused by uneven heating of the Earth's surface which makes pressure and density differences.

Air moves from low to high pressure and is deflected to the right by the Coriolis force in the Northern Hemisphere.

Wind is Horizontal movement of air, Convective Currents are vertical movements.

On short final pavement can cause updrafts and water or vegetation like trees can cause downdrafts.

sections.rawHtml:
A cloud ceiling is defined as the lowest layer that obscures more than half the sky so broken or overcast layers.

Clouds are caused by condensation when water vapor in rising air current cools to its dew point and condenses into visible moisture.

Most dangerous type of clouds are cumulonimbus clouds, lenticular clouds over mountains also indicate excessive turbulence (Lens Shaped).

Stratus - Lowest

Alto - Medium

Cirrus - High

sections.rawHtml:
Water holds its temperature better than land so it takes longer to heat up and cool down.

During the day the land air warms quicker and becomes less dense so it rises

The cooler air sill over the water then flows in to replace it causing a Sea Breeze.

At Night land cools quicker so the warmer air over the water rises and is replaced by the land air causing a Land Breeze.

sections.rawHtml:
Turbulent waves that form when stable air flows over a mountain.

They form above and downwind of the mountain and their presence can be known by lenticular clouds.

So in windy conditions the downwind side has generally worse weather as mountain waves can extend miles.

sections.rawHtml:
Hot air is less dense and can hold more moisture.

Dew Point is the temperature the air must be cooled to become fully saturated.

Once they are equal if any more moisture is added then the water vapor will turn into visible moisture.

Relative Humidity - The amount of moisture in the air compared to the total amount it could hold.

So a relative humidity of 65% means it's holding 65% of what it is capable of holding.

sections.title: Temperature Inversions

sections.rawHtml:
Three Types -

  • Convective: Uneven Heating of Earths surface, sunny afternoons with little wind cause bubbles of warm air to rise.
  • Mechanical: Caused by obstructions like mountains (Mountain Waves) or buildings.
  • Wind Shear: Turbulence generated between two wind currents - Temperature Inversions and Clear air turbulence around the jet stream.

Four Levels of Intensity -

  • Light - Slight changes in altitude or attitude, slight strain felt.
  • Moderate - Changes in altitude or attitude, positive control maintained, definite strain felt.
  • Severe - Large changes in altitude or attitude, may lose control momentarily, forceful strains felt.
  • Extreme - Aircraft violently tossed around, impossible to control, may lead to structural damage.

*Clear Air Turbulence (CAT) can be best located from PIREPs.

sections.title: Turbulence

sections.rawHtml:
Required to Form

Moisture | Unstable Air | Lifting Force


Stages

Cumulus - Strong Updrafts

Mature - Precipitation starts to fall creating downdrafts alongside the updrafts - Peak Intensity.

Dissipating - Mostly downdrafts


Types of Thunderstorms

Steady State - Driven by Fronts

Airmass - Naturally Formed from Air Masses

Embedded - Obscured by clouds often from occluded fronts

Squall Line - Long line of thunderstorms


*Thunderstorms bring turbulence, icing, hail, heavy rain, sometimes tornados.

*There are single cell, multi cell, and super cell thunderstorms based on their size.

*End of the mature stage is marked by an anvil cloud top.

*Don't turn back if you accidentally enter a thunderstorm, maintain attitude while letting others fluctuate, disengage autopilot.

Use an airspeed a little under maneuvering speed.

*Remain clear of thunderstorms by 20 miles to avoid strong winds and hail.

*Can cause microbursts which can have downdrafts up to 6000ft per minute.

sections.rawHtml:
Structural Icing requires Around Freezing Temperatures and Visible Moisture.

Three Types -

  • Clear Ice: Smooth ice that forms at temps just below freezing allowing it to spread across the surface, denser, heavier.
  • Rime Ice: Milky rough ice that forms at colder temps allowing the supercooled drops to freeze on impact.
  • Mixed Ice: Combination of Clear and Rime forms a temperatures in between the two.

*Ice is reported as Trace, Light, Moderate, Severe.

sections.rawHtml:
Radiation Fog - Occurs on cool, clear, calm nights where the ground cools the air above it quicker than air higher up.

Advection Fog - Often occurs with sea breezes and happens when moist air gets pushed over a colder surface cooling it down to its dew point.

Upslope Fog - Occurs when wind forces moist air up say a mountain cooling the moist air to its dew point.

Steam Fog - Occurs when cold air moves over warm water.


*Fog Forms either when air cools to it's dew point to become fully saturated or moisture is added for it to become fully saturated.

In Class A you use Flight levels and pressure altitudes - set your altimeter to 29.92

Requirements -

Current Instrument rating in an IFR approved aircraft on an IFR flight plan.

Mode C transponder with ADS-B Out.

definitions.rawText:
Each airport has tailored airspace to accommodate approach and departure operations, generally an upside down wedding cake extending up to 10000 MSL.
Bold Blue lines with altitudes listed on sectional chart.

Requirements 
Two Way Radio, Mode C Transponder and ADS-B Out both when within 30NM veil.
Must be cleared directly "into the bravo"

Underneath Class B Shelves and within B Corridors the speed restriction is 200 Knots.
Unless Aircrafts minimum safe speed is higher than the speed restriction.
ADS-B and Mode C Transponder Required within 30 NM Veil.

These are holes which VFR aircraft can fly through without Bravo Clearance, they each have their own procedures.
VFR Transition routes - Also exist but are still Bravo airspace and require clearance, just recommended flight paths for VFR Traffic.

Requirements -

Mode C transponder with ADS-B Out.

Airspeed less than Mach 1 above 10000ft MSL.

sections.rawHtml:
Class C

Tailored to traffic needs of primary airport. Usually has a 5 NM and 10 NM radius shelf and an 20 NM Outer Area.

Requirements to Enter

Two Way Radios, Mode C Transponder, ADS-B Out all required in and above Charlie Airspace.

Need to establish two way radio communications.

You Can get Class C Services from ATC within 20 NM outer area - Separation from IFR traffic etc.

Class G airspace is uncontrolled -> ATC services are not available.

Could fly IMC in G without an IFR flight plan except that is considered 91.13 dangerous and reckless aviation so you can't.

If there is a towered class G airport you still must be in communication within 4NM and 2500 AGL.

sections.rawHtml:
Acronyms - MCPRAWN TTS

  • Military Operation Area (MOA) - Used to separate IFR traffic from military operations and warn VFR traffic of possible high speed military activity.
  • Controlled Firing Areas (CFA) - Not Charted because there is a spotter looking out for aircraft to stop the potentially hazardous activities.
  • Prohibited Area - (P-40) Aircraft are prohibited to enter, examples include Camp David, National Mall, Heightened national security areas.
  • Restricted Area - (R-41) While active aircraft cannot enter, need permission from controlling agency when active. Contains activities hazardous to non participating aircraft.
  • Alert Area - Used to warn pilots of large volumes of training activity or unusual aerial activity.
  • Warning Area - (W-42) Extends starting 3 NM off the coast outwards and warns pilots of hazardous activity, use cation when entering.
  • National Security Area (NSA) - Where increased security is required for ground facilities, Pilots requested to avoid and sometimes prohibited based on NOTAMs.

Intercept Procedures if you accidentally bust restricted airspace -

Squawk 7700, communicate on 121.5, rock wings to acknowledge instructions, follow the interceptor aircraft.

*Bonus ADIZ - Air Defense Identification Zone, must have to way radio and mode C transponder to identify yourself and be on flight plan.

TRSA - Terminal Radar Service Area, Pilots encouraged to contact radio and get radar services.

Temporary Flight Restrictions (TFR) - Avoid traffic congestion over sporting events, protect President, etc.

SFRA - Special Flight Rules Area, Unique air traffic control rules apply here.
sections.rawText:
Acronyms - MCPRAWN TTS
Military Operation Area (MOA) - Used to separate IFR traffic from military operations and warn VFR traffic of possible high speed military activity.
Controlled Firing Areas (CFA) - Not Charted because there is a spotter looking out for aircraft to stop the potentially hazardous activities. 
Prohibited Area - (P-40) Aircraft are prohibited to enter, examples include Camp David, National Mall, Heightened national security areas.
Restricted Area - (R-41) While active aircraft cannot enter, need permission from controlling agency when active. Contains activities hazardous to non participating aircraft. 
Alert Area - Used to warn pilots of large volumes of training activity or unusual aerial activity.
Warning Area - (W-42) Extends starting 3 NM off the coast outwards and warns pilots of hazardous activity, use cation when entering.
National Security Area (NSA) - Where increased security is required for ground facilities, Pilots requested to avoid and sometimes prohibited based on NOTAMs.
Intercept Procedures if you accidentally bust restricted airspace -
Squawk 7700, communicate on 121.5, rock wings to acknowledge instructions, follow the interceptor aircraft. 
*Bonus ADIZ - Air Defense Identification Zone, must have to way radio and mode C transponder to identify yourself and be on flight plan.
 TRSA - Terminal Radar Service Area, Pilots encouraged to contact radio and get radar services.
 Temporary Flight Restrictions (TFR) - Avoid traffic congestion over sporting events, protect President, etc.
 SFRA - Special Flight Rules Area, Unique air traffic control rules apply here.
sections.title: Special Use Airspace

sections.rawHtml:
Minimum Safe Altitudes 91.119

Congested Areas - 1000 ft above the highest obstacle in a 2000 ft radius.

Sparsely Populated/ Water - 500 ft above any person vehicle or structure if there are any.

Other - 500 ft above the surface.

Always have to be able to make an emergency landing without undue hazard to persons or property on the surface.

*Pilots are strongly requested to stay at least 2000 ft above the surface of Wildlife Refuges.

Your Altitude above sea level (MSL) adjusted for standard pressure of 29.92

Found With: Standard altimeter setting - Current Setting * 1000 + Field Elevation, Set 29.92 into Kollsman Window on altimeter.

" High to Low look Out Below ".

In Cold Weather and low pressure you will be lower to the ground than what the altimeter makes you think.

The performance is worse because there are fewer air molecules for the engine, prop, and wings to use for thrust and list.

sections.rawHtml:
Forward CG: Increased Stall Speed but easier recovery, Slower Cruise speed, more stable but less controllable.

*Because the horizontal tail surfaces actually create negative lift so with forward CG more of that negative lift is being created

requiring the wings to create more lift with a higher AOA.

Rearward CG: Opposites - Decreased stall speed, higher cruise speed, less stable but more maneuverable.

* A Heavier plane overall has Higher Stall speeds, slower cruise speeds, longer landing and takeoff rolls.

sections.rawHtml:
Occurs from uncoordinated stalls where one wing is stalled more than the other.

Fours stages to a spin - Entry, Incipient, Fully developed, Recovery.

Incipient - First 2-4 turns where aerodynamic forces have not yet reached a balance.

Fully Developed - Rate of rotation, descent, and airspeed are all stabilized in a near vertical downward path.

Recover - PARE

Power Idle

Ailerons Neutral

Rudder Opposite of spin

Elevator move briskly forward to break stall

*Once established a spin can lose altitude at 10000ft per minute, spin itself is 1G recovery is 2.5G

During the Day it is still recommended above 10000 MSL

Altitudes are actually cabin pressure altitudes and can be lower than MSL with lower than standard altimeter settings

sections.rawHtml:
Gyroscopic Instruments

Power Sources/Principles

• Rigidity in Space / Vacuum: Attitude Indicator, Heading Indicator

• Precession / Electricity : Turn Coordinator (also rigidity in space)

Rigidity in Space : A spinning disk (like a gyro) resists changes to and maintains its orientation in space.

Precession : Force applied to a spinning disk is deflected 90 degrees in the direction of rotation.
sections.rawText:
Gyroscopic Instruments
Power Sources/Principles
	• Rigidity in Space / Vacuum: Attitude Indicator, Heading Indicator
	• Precession / Electricity : Turn Coordinator (also rigidity in space)
Rigidity in Space : A spinning disk (like a gyro) resists changes to and maintains its orientation in space.
Precession : Force applied to a spinning disk is deflected 90 degrees in the direction of rotation.

definitions.rawText:
Use Two Principles
Rigidity in Space - A spinning disk resists changes to and maintains its orientation in space.
Precession - Forces applied to spinning disks are deflected 90 degrees in the direction of rotation.

Weirdo - 30 degree canted gyro
Works on Precession and Electrical Power
Shows a slip when the ball swings outside the turn from not enough rudder, and a Skid when you use too much rudder and the ball swings into the turn.

Horizontal gyro
Works on Rigidity in Space and Vacuum Power
Has pendulous vanes to avoid precession errors.

Vertical Gyro
Works on Rigidity in Space and Vacuum Power
Susceptible to precession errors so you have to correct it around every 15 minutes or after large banks/ pitches.
The Earth's rotation also throws it off over time.

sections.rawHtml:
You turn on the battery to supply electricity to the starter and auxiliary pump.

Prime the engine to get some fuel in the cylinders.

The starter extends a gear that links with the flywheel which is a gear connected to the crankshaft,

This turns the crankshaft which is connected through gears to the magnetos

these then start generating electricity to the spark plugs to ignite the fuel in the cylinders.


Impulse Coupler - The Starter doesn't get enough RPMs to really get the mags going so an impulse coupler helps get the magneto spinning at first

to generate enough electricity for the spark plugs.

sections.title: Gyroscopic Intruments

definitions.rawText:
Uses a Pitot Tube and Static Port
All Three Instruments use the Static air but only the airspeed indicator uses the pitot tube for Ram Air.

Blockages
If just the front pitot tube hols is blocked the air will bleed out the drain hole and the Airspeed Indicator will read Zero.
If Both holes are blocked then the Airspeed Indicator will act like an Altimeter and change with climbs / descents. No Other Instruments will be affected. 
If just the Static Port is blocked the Airspeed Indicator will work like a reverse altimeter but still change with speeds also, but this means if you descend your airspeed could show up unusually high
and if you keep pulling power trying to fix this you could stall. 
The Altimeter will freeze at the altitude the blockage occurred and the VSI will return to 0.

Three Aneroid Wafers sealed to 29.92 Hg of air pressure. These expand / contract based on the static air around them, you adjust the needles default position with the Kollsman Window for different pressures. 
Going from high temperature to colder ones the altimeter can read higher than you actually are.

Diaphragms receive constant air flow to inflate or deflate in a VSI it comes from static air but in the Airspeed Indicator it is Ram air. Both then have static air going into the outer casing to compare to.

Takes 6-9 Seconds to show actual rate of climb or descent before that its just your trend.
If on the ground it is not reading 0 use whatever it is reading as 0.
This is the only real anti-ice equipment on the aircraft with pitot heat.

sections.rawHtml:
Turn Coordinator: Canted Horizontally mounted Gyro that is powered by electricity, the 30 degree canted angle allows it to sense the

Rate of Roll while still also giving the Rate of Turn like a Turn and Slip Indicator.

Avoids precession errors by having pendulous vanes that swing and cover air holes.

has to be adjusted to the current heading based on the magnetic compass initially and then every 15 mins

to account for precession throwing it off.

sections.rawHtml:
Attitude Heading Reference System (AHRS)

Replaces the Gyroscopic System with micro-electronic Gyros that use vibrations, accelerometers that use gravitational force, and a magnetometer or flux valve that measures the Earth's magnetic field strength and direction. Rate and tilt sensors.

PFD, MFD, Audio Panel, ADC, AHRS, Magnetometer, Datalink, etc.

There are two integrated avionics units and both would have to fail for us to lose nav and coms.

Potential Limitations of the G1000 is a tendency to over control the aircraft. Databases can be expired if not checked,

and it can make people focus to much inside the plane and not look outside.

sections.title: LRUs

sections.rawHtml:
Two small magnets inside a kerosene liquid attached to a pivot mount allowing them to move freely and remain aligned with magnetic north.

The vertical line showing your heading is the lubber line.

The fluid dampens oscillations and takes weight off the pivot.

Errors associates with the magnetic compass: Acronym - VDMONA

Variation - Difference between True and Magnetic North, Corrected for with Isogonic lines on sectional charts

Deviation - Magnetic fields within the aircraft messing with it's orientation

Magnetic Dip - Tendency to dip down to align with the vertical aspect of the magnetic lines that at the poles go straight down.

Oscillation - Erratic readings during turbulence from it bouncing around.

Northerly Turning Errors - UNOS, Undershoot North and Overshoot South: When turning to the North you undershoot the turn and vice versa

Acceleration Errors - ANDS, Accelerate North and Decelerate South: When not already facing North or South when you accelerate it will point North and vice versa

definitions.rawText: Attached to the blue prop control lever , moves the speeder spring up and down to move the flyweights inward or outward.
Pushes on the flyweights to adjust their default spot and thus the default spot of the pilot valve and prop during flight.

L Shaped and connected to the engine and the pilot valve | The Prop control moves these through the speeder spring to control the pilot valve | when the engine speeds up the weights move faster and centrifugal force makes them fly outward which also lifts the pilot valve up and lowers the angle of attack of the prop.
Moved by the flyweights and controls the amount of oil going to push on the prop and change its angle of attack.
Oil pressure comes from the engine oil.
Helps boost the oil pressure before going into the propeller hub for better and quicker responses from the propeller.

definitions.rawText: Reserve of Hydraulic Fluid used to retract and extend the gear.
Senses hydraulic pressure and uses it to indicate whether the gear is down, up, or in between with usually three green / red lights.
Releases the low pressure holding the gear in place with gravity then causing them to extend.

sections.title: Retractable Landing Gear

definitions.rawText:
Throttle controls amount of fuel/ air mixture going to cylinders, Mixture controls the amount of fuel in the mixture.
Uses 100LL or 100 - 100 represents the octane number the higher the number the more energy it takes to combust. 

Fuel injected systems are prone to vapor lock where fuel gets so hot it vaporizes in the fuel lines.
The fuel lines sit on top of the engine partially causing them to absorb a lot of it's heat so on really hot days it can be too much.

There are 56 total gallons and 53 usable gallons at max, 13 Fuel sumps and 3 fuel vents one on left wing and one in each fuel cap. 
3 Gallons are unusable because fuel is pulled slightly above the bottom of the tank to avoid bringing in contaminants. 
The Fuel Vents are to allow air to enter the tank to replace the fuel that is used up in order to avoid creating a vacuum potentially stopping fuel flow.
The wing vent also serves as an overflow port if the fuel heats up and expands.
A Reserve of about 1 gallon to make sure there is always a constant fuel supply.
Can only be used on left or right during level flight.

sections.rawHtml:
Tricycle Type, Steerable nose wheel and two main wheels.

Shock absorption provided by tubular spring steel main landing gear struts,

and air/oil oleo shock strut for the nose gear.

Oleo Strut - The piston you can see connect to the nose gear has some sort of oil in it,

on landing this gets pushed up into a cylinder above it which contains compressed air or nitrogen that cushions the blow.

The Shimmy Damper - Prevents the nose wheel from vibrating excessively during higher ground speeds,

contains hydraulic fluid is limited on how fast it can move side to side so it resits movement at higher speeds.

Nose gear connected to the Rudders via spring loaded steering bungee.
sections.rawText:
Tricycle Type, Steerable nose wheel and two main wheels.
Shock absorption provided by tubular spring steel main landing gear struts,
and air/oil oleo shock strut for the nose gear. 
Oleo Strut - The piston you can see connect to the nose gear has some sort of oil in it, 
on landing this gets pushed up into a cylinder above it which contains compressed air or nitrogen that cushions the blow.
The Torque Link - prevents the piston from rotating in the cylinder connected to both of them.
Shimmy Damper - Prevents the nose wheel from vibrating excessively during higher ground speeds,
contains hydraulic fluid is limited on how fast it can move side to side so it resits movement at higher speeds.
Nose gear connected to the Rudders via spring loaded steering bungee.
sections.title: Fuel System

definitions.rawText:
The engine spins the alternator belt which in turn spins a magnet inside a circular winding of wires generating electricity. 
Produces 60 Amps, 28 Volts - 4 more than the battery to charge it.
Volts are the pressure applied to or speed of the electrical current, while amps are the amount of electrical current.
Alternator generated AC and then a rectifier converts it into DC for consistent electricity. 
To prevent voltage from varying with RPM changes since the alternator is engine driven there is a voltage regulator to keep it close to 28 volts at all times.
This is in the form of an Alternator Control Unit (ACU) in our plane which adds over voltage protection. Above 32 Volts the ACU open the alt field circuit breaker stopping the alternator.

8 Amp Hours, 24 Volts
Means it can support 8 amp constantly for an hour.
It is a lead acid battery - same as cars.
There is also a standby battery that will the essential bus going but nothing else if the main battery fails.
Shows the batteries rate of charge with a positive indication or it's discharge with a negative one, it should be charging when the alternator is going.

LOW VOLTS - Means System voltage is below 24.5 which signifies the alternator not supplying the power it should be and the battery is being used.
STBY BATT - Means the standby battery has been discharging more than .5 amps for more than 10 seconds, meaning the alternator and main battery would not be working.
HIGH VOLTS - The system voltage is above 32 which means the ACU Alternator control unit has failed, so you must turn the alternator off yourself.

Electrical 1 and 2, Avionics 1 and 2, Cross feed and Essential
These are like power strips that connect various components of the electrical system to one bus which simplifies wiring and
makes it easier to take things offline by pulling a circuit breaker.
Circuit Breakers protect against excess current and heat which could create a fire hazard. The extra heat causes the metal conductor inside the circuit breaker to pop breaking the circuit.
The numbers on them represent the amount of amps it takes to pop and if one does you get one try after letting it cool off to reset it and see if it was a fluke.

sections.rawHtml:
Single disc, hydraulically actuated brake on each main gear wheel,

Each brake is connected by a small hydraulic line going to a master cylinder connected to the brake pedals.

There are two master cylinders one on each of the left seats brake pedals.

The Right seat breaks are mechanically linked to the left seats and push down on the master cylinders as well.

Pushing on the break pushes down on the master cylinders which sends hydraulic fluid through the lines

into the break assembly which then pushes against another piston that clamps the break pads

against the steel wheel disc that spin with the wheel, this creates friction slowing the rotation.


Hydraulic Fluid color is a light red

If the brakes feel spongy on landing you can try pumping them to build up pressure with the fluid.

sections.rawHtml:
Acronym - LHAND12348

  • Lycoming IO 360 L2A: Lycoming (Company) | Injected Opposed | 360 cubic inches of air displacement (total space inside cylinders) | L2A = Model number
  • Horizontally Opposed Cylinders
  • Air Cooled
  • Naturally Aspirated
  • Direct Drive
  • 180 Horsepower
  • 2 Magnetos
  • 360 cubic inch air displacement
  • 4 four stroke cylinders - intake, compression, power, exhaust
  • 8 Spark Plugs


Spark plugs ignite fuel/ air mixture in the cylinders causing a controlled explosion that pushes the pistons up and down,

these pistons are connected to the crankshaft rotating it which is directly connected to the propeller

so the prop rotates at the same speed as the crankshaft (Direct Drive).

sections.title: Engine

sections.rawHtml:
We have two magnetos for redundancy and better fuel burn connected each to a spark plug in each cylinder for a total of 8.

Consists of a Magnet geared to the engine which causes it to spin next to copper wires which generates electricity for the spark plugs.

Spark Plug Fouling - Caused by too rich a mixture at lower RPMs or running the engine too cold.

Leads to carbon deposits that make the engine run rougher and can reduce RPMs, can be noticed in Mag tests sometimes with roughness and higher drops.

Need to run the engine hotter and burn off these deposits to fix the issue.

If a mag doesn't drop at all it could be not grounding (turning off)
sections.rawText:
We have two magnetos for redundancy and better fuel burn connected each to a spark plug in each cylinder for a total of 8.
Consists of a Magnet geared to the engine which causes it to spin next to copper wires which generates electricity for the spark plugs.

sections.title: Magnetos

sections.rawHtml:
Receives Ram air from the intake on the bottom of the front engine cowling covered by an air filter.

This goes through an air box, if the filter gets blocked the engine creates a suction opening a spring loaded alternate air door.

This brings unfiltered air in which can reduce power around 10%.

after the air box it goes into a fuel / air control unit and then ducted other the engine cylinders.

This is a naturally aspirated system which means the intake doesn't use a turbo or supercharger.


Also Air cooled from air flowing over the cooling fins, as opposed to something like liquid cooling.

Ways to cool an engine - Decrease throttle, increase airspeed, enrich mixture. Oil also cools the engine.

Also Air cooled from air flowing over the cooling fins, as opposed to something like liquid cooling.
Ways to cool an engine - Decrease throttle, increase airspeed, enrich mixture. Oil also cools the engine.
sections.title: Air Induction System

sections.rawHtml:
Two Bladed Fixed pitch 76 inch propeller manufactured by McCauley. Made of aluminum alloy.

Can shave this blade down at most 1 inch.

The blade is twisted because the tip spins a lot faster traveling a longer distance in the same time.

It makes it generate uniform thrust along the propeller.

It is a middle pitch prop a combo of a climb and cruise, cruise ones have bigger angles to take bigger bites of air.

sections.rawHtml:
Tricycle Type, Steerable nose wheel and two main wheels.

Shock absorption provided by tubular spring steel main landing gear struts,

and air/oil oleo shock strut for the nose gear.

Oleo Strut - The piston you can see connect to the nose gear has some sort of oil in it,

on landing this gets pushed up into a cylinder above it which contains compressed air or nitrogen that cushions the blow.

The Shimmy Damper - Prevents the nose wheel from vibrating excessively during higher ground speeds,

contains hydraulic fluid is limited on how fast it can move side to side so it resits movement at higher speeds.

Nose gear connected to the Rudders via spring loaded steering bungee.
sections.rawText:
Tricycle Type, Steerable nose wheel and two main wheels.
Shock absorption provided by tubular spring steel main landing gear struts,
and air/oil oleo shock strut for the nose gear. 
Oleo Strut - The piston you can see connect to the nose gear has some sort of oil in it, 
on landing this gets pushed up into a cylinder above it which contains compressed air or nitrogen that cushions the blow.
The Torque Link - prevents the piston from rotating in the cylinder connected to both of them.
Shimmy Damper - Prevents the nose wheel from vibrating excessively during higher ground speeds,
contains hydraulic fluid is limited on how fast it can move side to side so it resits movement at higher speeds.
Nose gear connected to the Rudders via spring loaded steering bungee.
sections.title: Landing Gear

sections.rawHtml:
Single disc, hydraulically actuated brake on each main gear wheel,

Each brake is connected by a small hydraulic line going to a master cylinder connected to the brake pedals.

There are two master cylinders one on each of the left seats brake pedals.

The Right seat breaks are mechanically linked to the left seats and push down on the master cylinders as well.

Pushing on the break pushes down on the master cylinders which sends hydraulic fluid through the lines

into the break assembly which then pushes against another piston that clamps the break pads

against the steel wheel disc that spin with the wheel, this creates friction slowing the rotation.


Hydraulic Fluid color is a light red

If the brakes feel spongy on landing you can try pumping them to build up pressure with the fluid.

sections.rawHtml:
Oil Serves multiple Purposes in the Engine

1: Lubrication of Engine parts

2: Cooling of the Engine

3: Carrying away Contaminants

4: Helps provide a seal between the cylinder walls and pistons.


We need a minimum of 5 Quarts (School Policy 6) and can hold at most 8. Closer to 8 you can spray or burn oil out but can be used for long flights.

We have a Wet oil sump on our engine opposed to a dry one.

a Wet system is more simply with pan at the bottom that collects oil as gravity pulls it down, it then goes through a strainer

to the engine driven oil pump then the oil cooler and filter then a pressure relief valve which sends some back if pressure is too high,

then through the engine and then gravity pulls it back down to the sump pan.

A Dry system has a separate oil tank and uses a series of pump to keep oil circulating, needed for aerobatic planes.

Adding oil is considered basic upkeep.

Uses 2 Vacuums driven by engine geared to the crankshaft that suck air from the cabin.

If the pump gets too low of air pressure there are L VAC and R VAC annunciators, one for each vacuum.

Powers the Attitude Indicator and Heading Indicator which both use rigidity in space.

Susceptible to tumbling during excessive pitches or banks.

sections.rawHtml:
Carbon Monoxide is odorless, tasteless, and colorless.

There is a heater shroud around the exhaust pipe to trap hot air around it and lead it to the cabin for heat.

If the exhaust pipe gets cracked carbon monoxide from the exhaust could leak into the cabin from the heating vents.

Carbon Monoxide poisoning occurs because Carbon Monoxide attaches to hemoglobin 200 times easier than oxygen so it takes its spot in the blood.

Symptoms can be headaches, blurred vision, drowsiness, loss of muscle power.

Mitigated by turning heaters off, opening vents and windows, supplemental oxygen.

Compared to other hypoxias this one you usually don't feel euphoric just crappy.

sections.rawHtml:
Hypoxic - Caused by insufficient oxygen being available to the body. Stems from operating at high altitudes without supplemental oxygen, starts around 10000ft


Hypemic - When Hemoglobin isn't able to transport enough oxygen to the cells, Stems from Carbon Monoxide poisoning or blood donations.


Stagnant - Oxygen rich blood can't move around sufficiently, Stems from High G forces, extreme cold, limb going to sleep, heart attack.


Histotoxic - The inability of cells to be able to use oxygen because they are poison by alcohol or drugs.


Symptoms: Euphoria | Headaches | Impaired judgment | Blue fingertips | Tingling | Vision Worsens

It effects each person differently but if you suspect somebody has it provide supplemental oxygen declare emergency and descend.

FAA recommend using supplemental oxygen at 10000 ft during the day and 5000 at night.

sections.title: Types of Hypoxia

sections.rawHtml:
Caused by heavy breathing that leads to insufficient carbon dioxide in the blood.

Counteracted by slowing breathing or breathing into a paper bag to recirculate that Carbon Dioxide.

Symptoms: Lightheaded or dizzy | tingling | visual impairment | At worst unconsciousness

If it is a passenger experiencing it its not a huge deal if they pass out it will slow their breathing.

If you don't know whether its hyperventilating or hypoxia treat it as hypoxia.

sections.title: Hyperventilation

sections.rawHtml:
You should not fly while congested

It can lead to mucus blocks in the Eustachian tube that allows pressure to equalize in and out of the ear.

This can create a vacuum effect on descents that can cause severe ear pain, or a rupture.

Can be mitigated by pinching the nose and blowing, swallowing, chewing gum, and yawning.

Flying while congested can also lead to a sinus block in the nasal passages.

These can lead to excruciating pain, bloody mucus, teeth pain and occur on descents also.

These can both be mitigated in flight by descending slowly.

sections.title: Inner Ear / Sinus

sections.rawHtml:
A lack of orientation with regard to the position, attitude, or movement of the aircraft.

We use three sensory systems to ascertain our orientation.

Visual: Eyes - Most important, loss of visual cues typically leads to disorientation

Somatosensory: Nerves in the skin and muscles that use gravity and feeling.

Vestibular: Inner ear organs (semicircular canals) that use balance to sense position.

We use three sensory systems to ascertain our orientation.
Visual: Eyes - Most important, loss of visual cues typically leads to disorientation 
Somatosensory: Nerves in the skin and muscles that use gravity and feeling.

sections.title: Spatial Disorientation

sections.rawHtml:
Acronym - ICEFLAGS

  • Inversion: Abruptly going from climb to straight and level feeling like you are tumbling backwards / pitching up.
  • Coriolis: In a turn when you make an abrupt head movement creating a false sensation of a turn.
  • Elevator: Updrafts / Downdrafts make you feel like you are climbing or descending.
  • False Horizon: Lights or clouds can look like the horizon
  • Leans: Entering a bank slowly can be unnoticeable to the fluid in ears so when you level out it feels like a turn in the opposite direction.
  • Autokinesis: Flashing lights can appear to be moving when you stare at them or non flashing ones can appear to be flashing.
  • Graveyard Spiral: A prolonged constant rate turn can give the illusion you stopped turning you level out and think you are tuning in the opposite direction.
  • Somatogravic: Rapid decelerations or accelerations feels like pitching down or pitching up.


Visual Illusions

  • Runway Width Illusion - A narrower runway can make it look like you are higher than you are.

A Wider runway can make it seem like you are lower.

  • Sloping Runways - An upsloping runway makes it so you can see more of it like you would higher up so you think you are higher than you are.

A downsloping runway shows you less so you think you are lower than you are.

A Narrow Upsloping runway could make you think you are much higher than you actually are and you could run into the terrain.

*Featureless Terrain or rain/ haze can make you think you are higher than you actually are also.

sections.rawHtml:
You should not fly within 24 hours of going scuba diving if controlled ascents are necessary.

Else should wait at least 12 hours.

Increased pressure under water causing nitrogen to dissolve in your tissues

At altitude with lower pressure this nitrogen tries to bubble and escape in joints and other areas causing extreme pain,

this is called the bends.

Neutralizing: Recognize the hazardous thought, label it as hazardous, say the antidote.

Anti Authority: Don't tell me what to do | Follow the rules they are usually right

Impulsivity: Do it quickly | Not so fast, think first

Invulnerability: It won't happen to me | Taking chances is foolish

Macho: I can do it | Taking chances is foolish

Resignation: What's the use? | I can make a difference

Have to report accidents or serious incidents immediately to nearest NTSB office, then a written report within 10 days.

or substantial damage (Requiring major repair or replacement of component) to aircraft.

Simulates Takeoff / Go-Around Configuration

Power 1500 RPM

Hold altitude until 60 - 65 kts - some do 55 but then stall happens almost instantly

Then go Full Power and Pitch for 25 degrees

Hold until Stall occurs - Call Out Stall Horn

Recover

sections.rawHtml:
Power Off Stall - Simulates Landing Configuration Stall

Power 1800 RPM

Below 110 Kts - Flaps 10

Below 85 Kts - Flaps 20

Flaps 30

Pitch for 65 kts with a stabilized descent

Then power idle and pitch up to around 5 degrees

Hold until Stall occurs - Call Out Stall Horn

Recover

sections.rawHtml:
What: A max performance climb with 180 turn


Clean configuration

1500 ft AGL

105 knots - around 2300 RPM

Bug heading - you get +- 10 degrees

First 90 Degrees

Full power - stay level

30 degrees bank quickly

Then Slowly increase pitch to 15 degrees right at 90 degrees

Second 90 Degrees

Hold nose at 15 degrees - Requires more back pressure

Slowly bring bank to 0 right at 180 degrees

*Airspeed should end around 60 knots - stall speed is 48 clean - stall horn happens around 10 knots above that

sections.title: Steep Turns

sections.rawHtml:
What: 3x360 turns while descending and maintaining your distance around a point with wind correction


Clean configuration

80 knots

Finish no lower than 1500 ft AGL

Each 360 you should give yourself 1000 ft

So start at or above 4500 ft AGL

Have to use less than 60 degree bank

Airspeed and heading you get +- 10

Start

Find a point on the ground and put it under the wheel on your side

Start into a headwind - so the least steep bank to start - bug heading

Downwind you make it more steep

Tail wind is the most steep

Upwind is mid steep like downwind

Start power idle

Let nose come down and start turn

Use trim for airspeed

When you finish one 360 smoothly add power to at least green to clear the engine

Should be a few around 3 seconds to put it in and then a few to take it out

sections.rawHtml:
◊ Never go to full break

Why: Show the danger of adding too much bank on base to final and stall spins


Clean configuration

85 knots

No lower than 3000 ft AGL

No airspeed or heading requirements

Start

Power idle

Bank 45 degrees

Nose up/Hold Altitude to induce stall

At first indication - Acknowledge it

Go wings level and max power

Right rudder on recovery to the right

Climb out Vx or Vy

Level to Cruise

sections.title: Accelerated Stall

sections.rawHtml:
Lazy Eights

Clean configuration

Airspeed 105 knots

Bug heading

At or above 1500 AGL

Start

Bank and pitch Slowly to 15 for the first 45 degrees

Bank to 30 and pitch to 0 to 90 degrees

Bank 15 pitch around -10 to 135 degrees

Bank and pitch to 0 at 180

Then to the other side same thing

At each point need to be +- 10 knots +- 100 ft and +- 10 degrees heading

Should hit the degrees and pitch slowly right as you hit the degrees should never really be holding an attitude

Tips

Around 90 degrees marks make sure you are on top of rudder

sections.rawHtml:
Eights on Pylons

Pivotal altitude: Ground speed squared divided by 11.3 + elevation

Clean configuration

Doesn’t have the altitude restriction of 1500 AGL

Start at 2500 MSL

95 knots


Find two points

Get to pivotal altitude

Position for 45 degrees quartering tailwind

Bug heading. - entry heading is also exit heading

Fly until first point is abeam your shoulder

This has to be done with a crosswind from the points

When ground speed goes down pitch goes down and vice versa

You fly about 5 seconds when you level out

If the point starts to get in front of your wing you push forward and if it moves back you pull back

sections.rawHtml:
Pattern is the same until abeam the touchdown point then

Power idle

Continue downwind and turn base half the normal distance

When you level make sure you aren’t low

You want to start final high


If you have less than 10 total knots of wind in any direction go flaps 10 at power idle

If more than 10 knots don’t go flaps 10

Aim for 70 knots don’t force it though let it happen and hold it

sections.rawHtml:
1: Master Switch - OFF

2: Cabin Heat and Air - OFF

3: Fire Extinguisher - Use

4: Avionics Master - OFF

5: All Other Switches - OFF
sections.rawText:

4:  Avionics Master - OFF

sections.title: Electrical Fire (In Flight)

sections.rawHtml:
1: All Lights Off

2: Perform a Sideslip bringing the wing on fire up to keep it away from fuel tanks

3: Land ASAP
